tutorial.title: Vintage Cars Website
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use your knowledge of HTML to build a simple vintage car website

executableContent.instructions:
Let's use our HTML knowledge to create a vintage car website that links to the page to buy when users hit `Click here to buy!`.

We've already added the three HTML files you will be working on: one for a home page, one for a page to buy a car, and another one for a contact page.

You don't need to add anything right now. Take a look at the code that's already there.

1. `index.html` - Here, we'll add the code needed for the home page
2. `buycar.html` - Here, we'll add the code needed for the page to buy a vintage car.
3. `contact.html` - Here, we'll add the code needed for the contact page.
4. `styles.css` - This style sheet already has code that will style the elements to make the site look nicer. We'll learn all about this later.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Luxy Vintage Cars</title>
    <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: buycar.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Luxy Vintage Cars</title>
    <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: contact.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Luxy Vintage Cars</title>
    <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's start with our homepage.  We'll create our site's "header" by adding a logo, heading, and navigation links, and placing them into a `div` to group them together. 

`div` elements help us to divide up the page and to group related elements together.

1. Create a `div` element.
2. Inside the `div` element, create an `h1` element with the text `Luxy Vintage Cars`.
3. Below the `h1` element, create a `p` element with the text `We Sell Luxury Vintage Cars`.
4. Below the `p` element, create an `a` element with the text `Home`. Add an `href` with the value `index.html`.
5. Create a second `a` element with the text `Contact`. Add an `href` with the value `contact.html`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Luxy Vintage Cars</title>
    <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's create our list of vintage cars.

1. First, create an `h3` element underneath the closing `div` tag from the previous exercise. Add the text `"Cars For Sale"`.
2. Below the `h3`, create a `ul` element.
3. Inside the `ul` element, create the first `li` item.  Inside the `li`, create a `p` element with the text `"Buggy - $20,000 USD"`.
4. After the `p` element, create an `img` element.  Set the `src` to `"https://mimo.app/i/bluebuggy.png"`. Set the `width` to `"200"` and the `height` to `"150"`.
5. Wrap the `p` element and the `img` element in a `div` to group them together.  Look at the hint to see how it's done.
6. Repeat tasks 3-5 and create two more `li` items with the following data:
```
p text: Mustang - $25,000 USD
img src: https://mimo.app/i/mustang.png

p text: Chevrolet - $21,000 USD
img src: https://mimo.app/i/chevrolet.png
```

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add our link to navigate to our buy car page.

1. After the `ul` element, create an `a` element with an `href` with value `buycar.html`, and text `Click here to buy!`.
2. Try clicking the link to make sure it works properly and navigates us to the buy car page.  This page won't have any content, but we will be adding to it soon.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's do our contact page next.

1. Copy the `div` whose first element is a heading element `h1` that we created for our homepage. Paste it into the `body` element of `contact.html`.  Look at the hint if you need more help.
2. Under the closing tag of the `div`, create a `p` element with the text `Fill the form below and we'll get back to you as soon as we can!`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's create our contact form.

1. Under the `p` element, create a `div` element to hold our form.
2. Inside the `div`, create an `h3` element with the text `Contact Form`.
3. Below the `h3` element, create a `label` with the text `Name:`. Next, create a text `input` element with the correct value for the `type` attribute.  Wrap the `label` and the `input` in a `div` element to group them together.  Look at the hint to see how this is done.
4. Create a second `div` containing a `label` with the text `Email:` and an email `input`.
5. Create one more `div` containing a `label` with the text `Phone:` and a phone `input`.
6. After this `div` element but before our Contact form's closing `div` tag, create a `button` element with the text `Submit`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's add to our Buy Car page.

1. Copy the header we created on our homepage and paste it into the `body` element of the `buycar.html`.  Look at the hint if you need the header.
2. Under the header`div`, create another `div` element.  This will be used to hold our purchase car form.
3. Inside this `div`, create an `h3` element with the text `Purchase Your Vintage Car`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's add a way to select the car to purchase.  We'll use checkbox inputs for this.

1. Below the `h3` element, create a `label` with the text `Choose a car:`
2. Create a checkbox `input` element and an `em` element with the text `Buggy`.
3. Create a second checkbox `input` element and an `em` element with the text `Mustang`.
4. Create a third checkbox `input` element and an `em` element with the text `Chevrolet`.
5. Wrap the `label` element, `input` elements, and `em` elements in a single `div` element to group these elements together.  Look at the hint to see how this is done.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's finish our purchase form by adding a color-picking `input` and date `input`.

1. Below the `div` containing the checkbox inputs, create a `div` element.
2. Inside the `div`, create a `label` element with the text `Choose a color:` and a color `input`.
3. Below this `div`, create another `div` element.
4. Inside the `div`, create a `label` element with the text `Choose a pickup date:` and a date `input`.
5. After the `div` containing our date `input`, create a `button` element with the text `Purchase`.
